headline: Kellyanne Conway on how Comey memos vindicate Trump
subHeadline: On 'Watters' World,' counselor to president Trump discusses the release of the former FBI director's memos.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to "Watters' World." I am Jesse Watters. James Comey and Hillary Clinton, the perfect pair. That's the subject tonight of "Watters' Words." Donald Trump's rise to real estate reality TV and politics has left a lot of people in the dust.  The two most prominent opponents Trump has vanquished, James Comey and Hillary Clinton handled their losses in the exact same way and for the exact same reasons. We will break it down in a second, but here's the real reason this should matter to you.  Losing to Donald Trump has become a cottage industry in America. Certain individuals are now trafficking in their defeats for financial, psychological and reputational reasons. We want you to identify these people and their true motivations before drinking their Kool-Aid.  So, let's begin. Comey and Hillary fired and defeated by Trump. Both write books collecting multimillion dollar advances and a piece of the action on the sales side. Comey and Hillary both go on national mainstream media tours, free book promotion facilitated by friendly questions and largely ignoring territory where their narratives are challenged. A critical component to the media blitz is reputation rehab, getting their story out there. Their stories are the same. They are not really the losers. They are victims. Victims of unethical Trump who cheated them out of their rightful titles.  Both Comey and Hillary share in the same delusion. They are incapable of seeing the other side's viewpoint and unable to admit their own faults. It's too painful for them. Comey still can't see why Trump fired him because the president didn't trust him and thought he was incompetent; and Hillary, still can't see why she lost because Trump was a better campaigner and voters disliked her.  And because they are so self-righteous, they make excuses. The Russians, obstruction, collusion, sexism, the list goes on and on.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: The investigation that they conducted ended in July, it was over and then it was reignited. Comey was more than happy to talk about my e-mails.   You had Citizens United come to its full fruition. If you look at Facebook, the vast majority of the news items posted were fake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The constant rewriting of history is the result of obsession with Donald Trump. Psychologically, the inability to reconcile their loss with the truth. This is why Comey wrote creepy passages about Trump's skin, hair and hands and why Hillary won't exit the stage gracefully.   In fact, Comey and Hillary truly believe Trump is obsessed with them. It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: He's tweeted at me probably 50 times. I have been gone for a year, I am like a breakup he can't get over.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The last thing that ties Comey and Hillary together, potential criminal acts. House Republicans have just issued criminal referrals for both of them to the Attorney General's Office and we will discuss that later tonight.  But here's the bottom line, there is a mountain of evidence Comey and Hillary committed crimes, but no evidence so far of Trump committing any. So, now you know how to spot the anti-Trump hustlers. Look for the pattern, profit, pain and PR.  Here to respond, former House -- White House Communications Director, Anthony Scaramucci, we are going to the Kellyanne Conway segment next because we want to talk about the Comey memos, but now I want to talk about the collapse of James Comey, but before that, what do you think of that brilliant commentary?

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, it was brilliant but I almost thought you needed like a drug on the table here that you were going to recommend to the people to take it after they been vanquished by the president, but...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think chardonnay is what Hillary is taking.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: The only thing you left out in my humble opinion, is that neither of them like people. The president likes people. At the end of the day, there is a gregarious nature to his personality when he is campaigning.  These guys like to closet themselves, so often...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, true.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: ... that what ends up happening is, it's that even if you like them, the more time you spend with them, you end up liking them less.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, socially awkward individuals.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: So, that's the big issue. And the last piece is typically, I mean, you don't like people, you think you are superior to people. The president doesn't think he's superior to anybody. All the president is trying to do is be a patriotic American and make very smart decisions on behalf of all the American people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you don't think you're a superior person. You actually think you are an inferior person to most people.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Yes, that is 100% correct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very humble.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Because I am a Roman Catholic. And so you learn that when you go to -- did you go to catechism?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, I did not. I went to Quaker school.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: You see, if you had gone to catechism, your whole life would have been different, okay. It would have been Watters' Universe as opposed to just "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right, I need a little more ego in my life.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: You would have the whole galaxy, Jesse. But at the end of the day, that's the problem. And so the president is probably snickering at the whole thing. Director Comey thinks that it's a bad breakup for the president. He could care less.  He's hitting him because he doesn't like to be hit and he comes up up with nicknames and I am sure there will be therapy as a result of those nicknames.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Shady James -- that was one of my favorites.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: The slime ball one was a little rough.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The slime ball -- that was pretty rough.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, let's listen to James Comey in his own words with George Stephanopoulos talking about the president.

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know whether the current president of the United States was with prostitutes peeing on each other in Moscow in 2013. It's possible, but I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is the head of FBI. He doesn't know and it's possible.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: It's totally impossible, and by the way, the president something really funny in his press conference in January 2017 before he was inaugurated. He said, "I am a germophobe."   You know, I mean, I don't think he's anywhere near urination. It's just a ridiculous thing to distract from the agenda and to distract from the really good policies that have been implemented. And so that's what they've got to do.  I mean, it's politics of distraction, scandals incorporated and all this stuff. I am a little upset with the director though because he came across when he was in New York as a straight up guy and the power went to his head and now he's actually equivocating in a way that even he doesn't understand. At one point, he said on the BBC a couple of night ago that he wouldn't give the president, if he was the Director, he wouldn't give the president certain intelligence information, but you just wrote a 350-page book about sanctimony and loyalty and process and rule of law, but now you're above the law and making decisions that would abrogate authority from the Commander-in-Chief? This is nonsensical stuff.  My recommendation to him is get off the air, take a chill and develop a little bit of self-awareness about the problems you yourself have because guess what? We all have problems.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're talking to me.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: You and me. Like my phonebook is a problem, but other people like have thin sheets of paper problems.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. This is also, George Stephanopoulos and James Comey. This did not make air, but we have the transcript. And there's probably a reason this doesn't make air on ABC News, Sunday. Listen to this: George Stephanopoulos says, "What about the rest of the Steele dossier? Has it checked out? Is it a credible document?"  And James Comey says the answer is, "I don't know." This is huge, Anthony and this is why, because you are only allowed to present credible substantiated document to a FISA judge when you are looking to get a warrant on another American. If the FBI Director knows or doesn't know about the credibility of a document and he's proffering that to a FISA judge, that's perpetrating fraud on a FISA court judge.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: And moreover, we learn that some of the documents, the memos that he turned over actually had confidential information and the ones that he leaked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: So, that could be a problem for him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, yes, he's looking at some serious consequences they are as well.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: So, that's another reason to get off the air.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, he's got to sell books.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: He's got to sell books. I think he's going to peat around on the books. Have you read the book?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You think so? No, we've read excerpts.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, I read the book last weekend. I mean, listen, there's a lot -- and I want to be fair to him. I love his upbringing. I love a lot of things that he says about the FBI, but I think he's got the whole thing wrong with the sanctimony. And just is another example of that where you're splitting things in a way that is not fair to the president and it's a lot of partisanship in there. Or if it's not partisanship, I'll go one step further and say, it's the politics of personal dislike.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: If you don't like the person, so now you're going to curve the rules to affect and hurt the person. It's unfair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he did not like the president. McCabe, his number two did not like the president. We know Clapper and Brennan didn't like the president.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: And he didn't think the president was going to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. He didn't think the president was going to win. Obviously, a very biased individual. I don't know how he can be a witness in any sort of Mueller case. I think he's totally discredited himself.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: It's great thinking about "Watters' World" you and I are both very biased, but at least we're right up front with the bias.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true, and are you growing your hair out? It's looks very coifed.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: No, no. I am using your texture spray. I went in there. I said, Jesse has got less hair than me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's proprietary.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: But he looks like he has more hair than me on stage, so I put a little of that texture spray and I looks like an Italian chia pet now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Very happy with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Looking good. Thanks, Anthony. All right, here with more on the Comey fallout, actor Dean Cain. Okay, Dean, I want to show you my -- I know you like the comment that I made...

utterances.speaker: DEAN CAIN, AMERICAN ACTOR
utterances.sentences: I want some of the hairspray.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: I want the hairspray.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know. You know what? You actually might have better hair than Anthony and myself. I hate to say that. Anthony is still here. Anthony, you can leave now.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: No, I am looking at Dean's hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can leave. We're done talking with you.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: Text me a picture of that hairspray that you're using, Dean, okay?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, and send that over here. I want a shipment. I wasn't going to bring this up with you. I never got around with Anthony because he was talking too much, but the Democratic Party has filed a lawsuit. It is suing Russia, Donald Trump -- the campaign, Kushner, Donald Trump, Jr., WikiLeaks -- they are suing everybody because I guess, they're just sore losers and they can't accept the defeat.  What do you think about that lawsuit?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: I am thinking that's not going to win. I think they're not going to get it, but you know what it does? It just keeps muddying the water. It keeps keeping it out there. It keeps that same narrative going and that's what they want to do. It's just -- they're just going to keep it going and we're going to hear about it and listen to it and muck rake and you know, anytime that Comey can get out there and say you know, things like I can't verify there was peeing and this -- they just keep saying those same things and after a while, you start believe it as fact.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's repetition and it works on half the public and it looks like the Mueller investigation is not really going the way the Democrats want it to go, so they are throwing this frivolous lawsuit out there. So, James Comey was asked about Hillary destroying evidence. Remember, they smashed the Blackberries with hammers? They bleached all of their servers. Listen to James Comey's response on radio. Here it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why wouldn't smashing the cell phones and the destruction of thousands of e-mails during an investigation clearly be obstruction of justice?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: That's a great question. That's the first time I've been asked that. And the answer is, it would depend upon what the intent of the people doing it was. Lots of people smash their cell phones so they're not sold on the secondary market and your personal stuff ends up in somebody else's hands, but if you smash your cell phone knowing that investigators want it and that they've got a subpoena for it for example, that is a different thing and can be obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, lots of people smash their cell phones. Anthony is still here, by the way. He's laughing...

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: I am hoping to you've more air time. You get going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, you've never smashed your cell phone. Have you ever smashed your cell phone, Dean?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: No, never. Not one time. I mean, by accident...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You dropped it...

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course. It takes me a number to get there. But listen, I mean, I take my phone and I clear it and then I resell because you want some money back on that. Not lots of people smash their cell phones because they want to hide their personal information. You can get rid of that. It's clear what happened there. Everybody knows what happened. They smashed their cell phones to get rid of any evidence. It's so blatant. It's unreal and the bleach bit, and things like that, I mean, it's so obvious, it's just embarrassing. It's like...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Could you imagine...

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: It doesn't pass mustard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Could you imagine if -- you know, there were some subpoenas out with Michael Cohen or Donald Trump, and we found out that Donald Trump or Michael Cohen or Don, Jr., had literally taken hammers and smashed their Blackberries and then bleached their servers on their computer networks? What do you think the mainstream media would have said if that had happened but on the other side?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: Armageddon. The end of the world as we know it. It would have been insanity. Volcanoes would have erupted. It would have been insane. And you know, the scales of justice are supposed to be equal. They are clearly not. There are rules for one group and there are rules for the rest of us, and those guys, you know, someone doesn't have their thumb on the scale of justice, there are entire people standing on the scale and making it completely -- it's ridiculous. I mean, it's literally a joke.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, so speaking of ridiculous and a joke, here again is James Comey trying to have it both ways when it comes to telling the truth. Listen to what he said to George Stephanopoulos about the president lying?

utterances.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOLOUS, AMERICAN JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Are you thinking President Trump is a liar?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I was obviously concerned about that earlier having watched him on the campaign. That he is someone for whom the truth is not a high- value.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so this is just days later, he goes on "The View" and says this about lying.

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: Good people lie. I lay out in the book, I think I am a good person, where I've lied.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so when the president lies, he's an evil man, and when anybody else lies, they could be good people.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.sentences: Of course, those are the scales of justice. Stand on this side and it's ridiculous. The longer this book tour continues for James Comey, the worse he looks. And the more he says -- I am surprised that he's out there saying so much. He's like one of those criminals that think they are so much smarter than the investigators and they keep talking and they keep talking. He's starting to dig big holes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're right. That's a great point. All right, Dean, I've got to run. Anthony's got to get out of here. We're keeping him, so we're going to go to break.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.sentences: I'm back here smashing my cell phone, Dean. I hope you didn't hear it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just to try to keep it down, all right? All right, the Comey memos, did the former FBI Director sign his own prison sentence? The White House with reaction up next.  James Comey wrote memos memorializing his private conversations with the president. After he was fired, he leaked these memos in order to trigger the appointment of a Special Counsel. Finally, those memos, somewhat redacted, were handed to Congress and "Watters' World" got its hands on them. President Trump claiming victory after the release of the Comey memos, and "James Comey memos just out and show clearly that there was no collusion and no obstruction. Also, he leaked classified information. Wow. Will the witch hunt continue? And later adding, "So, General Michael Flynn's life can be totally destroyed while Shady James Comey can leak and lying and make lots of money from a third-rate book that should never have been written. Is that really the way life in America is supposed to work? I don't think so." Comey was asked about leaking classified information on CNN.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, ANCHOR, CNN
utterances.sentences: Senator Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee says that there are seven memos. He says four of them are classified, is that right?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know because I don't have the memos. I don't know exactly how many there are. Some may be memos, some may be emails. There's somewhere between five and ten, it may be seven, it may be eight. I don't remember.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He doesn't remember. He doesn't know. Here to react, counsel to the president, Kellyanne Conway. My favorite part of the memo, Kellyanne was when he claims he's not a leaker. Listen to this, he says, "I explained that he could count on me to always tell the truth. I said, I don't do sneaky things. I don't leak. I don't do weasel moves." And then months later, he leaks and does a weasel move.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He does and if you're going to have the word lies on the title of your book, make sure you're not someone who tells them, and if you're going to have the word leadership in your book, make sure that you've displayed a modicum of leadership. The number one and two at the FBI, Jim Comey and Andrew McCabe are both known leakers. Admittedly, Andrew McCabe just this week, Jesse he is now being referred for criminal charges because they were leaking and lying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: For lies.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: And the lying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: For lies.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: And three -- at least under oath. Also, this week, McCabe's attorney went after James Comey for saying -- for Jim Comey pretending that he didn't know Andrew McCabe was leaking to the media. Now, let's review. This is a president that came to Washington and promised to be a disruptor, and be more transparent and accountable, but he's running into buzz saws begging at the very tippy top of the FBI. Where you have got the number one and the number two leaking, lying, exchanging leaks. Jim Comey, who takes all of these fastidious notes in the vehicle when he exits meetings with president-elect and President Donald Trump can't remember when he's asked by Jake Tapper, not even under oath. He's asked by what he thinks is going to be a friendly media source, media person, he is asked how many, "Um, I don't remember."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you know, what he never took any memos when he spoke to President Obama, Loretta Lynch.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: Well, he didn't, never. Never. He never did that...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Or Eric Holder.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: And speaking of Loretta Lynch, Jesse, please because nobody has said it the whole week, can we break news on your TV and your TV show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: You've got to go read the Comey memos which are much better than the Comey book, but if you must read both, Jim Comey has some kind of weird problem with powerful African-American woman. He goes after Condoleezza Rice and he goes after Loretta Lynch. In fact, in of this memos...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he took a shot at Loretta Lynch, and said Eric Holder was much smoother, most sophisticated...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: And was more sophisticated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's now like he's making enemies everywhere -- McCabe, Loretta Lynch...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: Do you think -- that's right...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Democratic item.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: Loretta Lynch, Condoleezza Rice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Republican item. Let me get to another part of the memo that I found interesting here. He says, "He said that if there were some satellite..." he means President Trump, "... I took this to mean some associates of his or his campaign, that did something meaning..." meaning collude, "... it would be good to find out, but that he hasn't done anything and I hoped we would find a way to get out that he weren't investigating." So, the memo proves that President Trump wasn't obstructing. He was telling the FBI Director, go look and investigate if there was any collusion...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: It is the opposite of obstruction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Of me or any of my people.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: It is the exact opposite of obstruction, which is to say, "Hey, I'd like to know too. I don't think so, but go ahead and find out." And you know what? They've been going ahead and finding out for over a year, and to what (inaudible)...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Almost two years now, Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: Almost two years, that's a good point. Almost two years. But, let's also review that this is a man who thought somebody else would win the election. Definitely wanted her to win the election and said, "I could not cast a vote. I need the FBI to be independent. "So, you couldn't cast a vote in the privacy of the ballot box or through the mail box?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Such a political animal.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: He didn't vote because he didn't Hillary Clinton needed his help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: She's ever going to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, he had his finger in the wind and someone said this, I think it was Byron York who made a great point. So, the first meeting you have with the president-elect and you're the FBI Director and you hand him a paper saying that there is shady stuff that Russia has on you. Why do you think President Trump was saying, you know what, loyalty is pretty important, probably because President Trump thought he might be being blackmailed by the FBI director? I mean, that's what I would have thought if the first meeting with the guy, he comes to me and says we have all this dirt on you allegedly from the Russians. I would have been a little suspicious. He was probably just trying to get a read on the guy.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: It's a very foozy situation actually, if you go back and think about it. This is an FBI director who didn't bother to go meet the president-elect until two full months after the election. And he ambles his way up to New York finally, 14 days before the inauguration and laid this bomb at the feet of the president-elect after everybody else left the room, but made clear to the president then, when he made clear to him many other times before, but failed to disclose publicly, which is that the president himself was not under investigation. He refused to say that...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He told him three times he wasn't under investigation.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: He told him at least three times, but wouldn't say it publicly. This person, this Comey guy who had no problem leaking information to the New York Times asking McCabe to do it to the Wall Street Journal at least doing it with his knowledge and then leaking it with an eye toward and a hope to getting -- triggering a special counsel, which is what happened. Why not just tell the public that the FBI director told the president-elect that he is not under investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, why not, Kellyanne? Well, that's a great point because we have it right here. Because again, President Trump asking the FBI Director, tell me what you just said before. I am not under investigation. Say that to the general public. He says, "I returned the president's call this morning. We spoke for about four minutes. He said he was following up to see if I did what he had asked last time, getting out that he was personally not under investigation. I replied that I had passed the request to the Acting AG and had not heard back from him." So, why is Shady James Comey, love the new nickname by the way, why is he slow walking the effort to make the public aware that the president of the United States is not under investigation. Why would he do that?

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.sentences: Well, he doesn't have a good answer for that himself. If I had to guess, because the wrong person won the election. He was taking all types of incoming from his friends in the Democratic Party. The people who had been investigating Hillary Clinton at the highest levels of the FBI, who we know through their sexting now, I mean, texting now, Jesse. I didn't like President Trump very much. utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, let's listen to James Comey in his own words with George Stephanopoulos talking about the president.

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.utterance: I don't know whether the current president of the United States was with prostitutes peeing on each other in Moscow in 2013. It's possible, but I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is the head of FBI. He doesn't know and it's possible.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: It's totally impossible, and by the way, the president something really funny in his press conference in January 2017 before he was inaugurated. He said, "I am a germophobe." You know, I mean, I don't think he's anywhere near urination. It's just a ridiculous thing to distract from the agenda and to distract from the really good policies that have been implemented. And so that's what they've got to do. I mean, it's politics of distraction, scandals incorporated and all this stuff. I am a little upset with the director though because he came across when he was in New York as a straight up guy and the power went to his head and now he's actually equivocating in a way that even he doesn't understand. At one point, he said on the BBC a couple of night ago that he wouldn't give the president, if he was the Director, he wouldn't give the president certain intelligence information, but you just wrote a 350-page book about sanctimony and loyalty and process and rule of law, but now you're above the law and making decisions that would abrogate authority from the Commander-in-Chief? This is nonsensical stuff. My recommendation to him is get off the air, take a chill and develop a little bit of self-awareness about the problems you yourself have because guess what? We all have problems.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you're talking to me.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: You and me. Like my phonebook is a problem, but other people like have thin sheets of paper problems.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. This is also, George Stephanopoulos and James Comey. This did not make air, but we have the transcript. And there's probably a reason this doesn't make air on ABC News, Sunday. Listen to this: George Stephanopoulos says, "What about the rest of the Steele dossier? Has it checked out? Is it a credible document?" And James Comey says the answer is, "I don't know." This is huge, Anthony and this is why, because you are only allowed to present credible substantiated document to a FISA judge when you are looking to get a warrant on another American. If the FBI Director knows or doesn't know about the credibility of a document and he's proffering that to a FISA judge, that's perpetrating fraud on a FISA court judge.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: And moreover, we learn that some of the documents, the memos that he turned over actually had confidential information and the ones that he leaked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: So, that could be a problem for him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, yes, he's looking at some serious consequences they are as well.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: So, that's another reason to get off the air.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's got to sell books.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: He's got to sell books. I think he's going to peat around on the books. Have you read the book?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think so? No, we've read excerpts.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, I read the book last weekend. I mean, listen, there's a lot -- and I want to be fair to him. I love his upbringing. I love a lot of things that he says about the FBI, but I think he's got the whole thing wrong with the sanctimony. And just is another example of that where you're splitting things in a way that is not fair to the president and it's a lot of partisanship in there. Or if it's not partisanship, I'll go one step further and say, it's the politics of personal dislike.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: If you don't like the person, so now you're going to curve the rules to affect and hurt the person. It's unfair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he did not like the president. McCabe, his number two did not like the president. We know Clapper and Brennan didn't like the president.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: And he didn't think the president was going to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. He didn't think the president was going to win. Obviously, a very biased individual. I don't know how he can be a witness in any sort of Mueller case. I think he's totally discredited himself.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: It's great thinking about "Watters' World" you and I are both very biased, but at least we're right up front with the bias.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true, and are you growing your hair out? It's looks very coifed.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: No, no. I am using your texture spray. I went in there. I said, Jesse has got less hair than me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's proprietary.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: But he looks like he has more hair than me on stage, so I put a little of that texture spray and I looks like an Italian chia pet now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: Very happy with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Looking good. Thanks, Anthony. All right, here with more on the Comey fallout, actor Dean Cain. Okay, Dean, I want to show you my -- I know you like the comment that I made...

utterances.speaker: DEAN CAIN, AMERICAN ACTOR
utterances.utterance: I want some of the hairspray.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I want the hairspray.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. You know what? You actually might have better hair than Anthony and myself. I hate to say that. Anthony is still here. Anthony, you can leave now.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: No, I am looking at Dean's hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can leave. We're done talking with you.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: Text me a picture of that hairspray that you're using, Dean, okay?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and send that over here. I want a shipment. I wasn't going to bring this up with you. I never got around with Anthony because he was talking too much, but the Democratic Party has filed a lawsuit. It is suing Russia, Donald Trump -- the campaign, Kushner, Donald Trump, Jr., WikiLeaks -- they are suing everybody because I guess, they're just sore losers and they can't accept the defeat. What do you think about that lawsuit?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: I am thinking that's not going to win. I think they're not going to get it, but you know what it does? It just keeps muddying the water. It keeps keeping it out there. It keeps that same narrative going and that's what they want to do. It's just -- they're just going to keep it going and we're going to hear about it and listen to it and muck rake and you know, anytime that Comey can get out there and say you know, things like I can't verify there was peeing and this -- they just keep saying those same things and after a while, you start believe it as fact.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's repetition and it works on half the public and it looks like the Mueller investigation is not really going the way the Democrats want it to go, so they are throwing this frivolous lawsuit out there. So, James Comey was asked about Hillary destroying evidence. Remember, they smashed the Blackberries with hammers? They bleached all of their servers. Listen to James Comey's response on radio. Here it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Why wouldn't smashing the cell phones and the destruction of thousands of e-mails during an investigation clearly be obstruction of justice?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.utterance: That's a great question. That's the first time I've been asked that. And the answer is, it would depend upon what the intent of the people doing it was. Lots of people smash their cell phones so they're not sold on the secondary market and your personal stuff ends up in somebody else's hands, but if you smash your cell phone knowing that investigators want it and that they've got a subpoena for it for example, that is a different thing and can be obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, lots of people smash their cell phones. Anthony is still here, by the way. He's laughing...

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: I am hoping to you've more air time. You get going.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, you've never smashed your cell phone. Have you ever smashed your cell phone, Dean?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: No, never. Not one time. I mean, by accident...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You dropped it...

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, of course. It takes me a number to get there. But listen, I mean, I take my phone and I clear it and then I resell because you want some money back on that. Not lots of people smash their cell phones because they want to hide their personal information. You can get rid of that. It's clear what happened there. Everybody knows what happened. They smashed their cell phones to get rid of any evidence. It's so blatant. It's unreal and the bleach bit, and things like that, I mean, it's so obvious, it's just embarrassing. It's like...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine...

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: It doesn't pass mustard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine if -- you know, there were some subpoenas out with Michael Cohen or Donald Trump, and we found out that Donald Trump or Michael Cohen or Don, Jr., had literally taken hammers and smashed their Blackberries and then bleached their servers on their computer networks? What do you think the mainstream media would have said if that had happened but on the other side?

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Armageddon. The end of the world as we know it. It would have been insanity. Volcanoes would have erupted. It would have been insane. And you know, the scales of justice are supposed to be equal. They are clearly not. There are rules for one group and there are rules for the rest of us, and those guys, you know, someone doesn't have their thumb on the scale of justice, there are entire people standing on the scale and making it completely -- it's ridiculous. I mean, it's literally a joke.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so speaking of ridiculous and a joke, here again is James Comey trying to have it both ways when it comes to telling the truth. Listen to what he said to George Stephanopoulos about the president lying?

utterances.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOLOUS, AMERICAN JOURNALIST
utterances.utterance: Are you thinking President Trump is a liar?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.utterance: Yes. I was obviously concerned about that earlier having watched him on the campaign. That he is someone for whom the truth is not a high- value.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so this is just days later, he goes on "The View" and says this about lying.

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.utterance: Good people lie. I lay out in the book, I think I am a good person, where I've lied.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so when the president lies, he's an evil man, and when anybody else lies, they could be good people.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Of course, those are the scales of justice. Stand on this side and it's ridiculous. The longer this book tour continues for James Comey, the worse he looks. And the more he says -- I am surprised that he's out there saying so much. He's like one of those criminals that think they are so much smarter than the investigators and they keep talking and they keep talking. He's starting to dig big holes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're right. That's a great point. All right, Dean, I've got to run. Anthony's got to get out of here. We're keeping him, so we're going to go to break.

utterances.speaker: SCARAMUCCI
utterances.utterance: I'm back here smashing my cell phone, Dean. I hope you didn't hear it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just to try to keep it down, all right? All right, the Comey memos, did the former FBI Director sign his own prison sentence? The White House with reaction up next. James Comey wrote memos memorializing his private conversations with the president. After he was fired, he leaked these memos in order to trigger the appointment of a Special Counsel. Finally, those memos, somewhat redacted, were handed to Congress and "Watters' World" got its hands on them. President Trump claiming victory after the release of the Comey memos, and "James Comey memos just out and show clearly that there was no collusion and no obstruction. Also, he leaked classified information. Wow. Will the witch hunt continue? And later adding, "So, General Michael Flynn's life can be totally destroyed while Shady James Comey can leak and lying and make lots of money from a third-rate book that should never have been written. Is that really the way life in America is supposed to work? I don't think so." Comey was asked about leaking classified information on CNN.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, ANCHOR, CNN
utterances.utterance: Senator Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee says that there are seven memos. He says four of them are classified, is that right?

utterances.speaker: COMEY
utterances.utterance: I don't know because I don't have the memos. I don't know exactly how many there are. Some may be memos, some may be emails. There's somewhere between five and ten, it may be seven, it may be eight. I don't remember.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He doesn't remember. He doesn't know. Here to react, counsel to the president, Kellyanne Conway. My favorite part of the memo, Kellyanne was when he claims he's not a leaker. Listen to this, he says, "I explained that he could count on me to always tell the truth. I said, I don't do sneaky things. I don't leak. I don't do weasel moves." And then months later, he leaks and does a weasel move.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: He does and if you're going to have the word lies on the title of your book, make sure you're not someone who tells them, and if you're going to have the word leadership in your book, make sure that you've displayed a modicum of leadership. The number one and two at the FBI, Jim Comey and Andrew McCabe are both known leakers. Admittedly, Andrew McCabe just this week, Jesse he is now being referred for criminal charges because they were leaking and lying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: For lies.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And the lying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: For lies.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And three -- at least under oath. Also, this week, McCabe's attorney went after James Comey for saying -- for Jim Comey pretending that he didn't know Andrew McCabe was leaking to the media. Now, let's review. This is a president that came to Washington and promised to be a disruptor, and be more transparent and accountable, but he's running into buzz saws begging at the very tippy top of the FBI. Where you have got the number one and the number two leaking, lying, exchanging leaks. Jim Comey, who takes all of these fastidious notes in the vehicle when he exits meetings with president-elect and President Donald Trump can't remember when he's asked by Jake Tapper, not even under oath. He's asked by what he thinks is going to be a friendly media source, media person, he is asked how many, "Um, I don't remember."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you know, what he never took any memos when he spoke to President Obama, Loretta Lynch.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Well, he didn't, never. Never. He never did that...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or Eric Holder.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And speaking of Loretta Lynch, Jesse, please because nobody has said it the whole week, can we break news on your TV and your TV show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: You've got to go read the Comey memos which are much better than the Comey book, but if you must read both, Jim Comey has some kind of weird problem with powerful African-American woman. He goes after Condoleezza Rice and he goes after Loretta Lynch. In fact, in of this memos...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he took a shot at Loretta Lynch, and said Eric Holder was much smoother, most sophisticated...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And was more sophisticated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's now like he's making enemies everywhere -- McCabe, Loretta Lynch...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Do you think -- that's right...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Democratic item.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Loretta Lynch, Condoleezza Rice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Republican item. Let me get to another part of the memo that I found interesting here. He says, "He said that if there were some satellite..." he means President Trump, "... I took this to mean some associates of his or his campaign, that did something meaning..." meaning collude, "... it would be good to find out, but that he hasn't done anything and I hoped we would find a way to get out that he weren't investigating." So, the memo proves that President Trump wasn't obstructing. He was telling the FBI Director, go look and investigate if there was any collusion...

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: It is the opposite of obstruction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Of me or any of my people.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: It is the exact opposite of obstruction, which is to say, "Hey, I'd like to know too. I don't think so, but go ahead and find out." And you know what? They've been going ahead and finding out for over a year, and to what (inaudible)...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Almost two years now, Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Almost two years, that's a good point. Almost two years. But, let's also review that this is a man who thought somebody else would win the election. Definitely wanted her to win the election and said, "I could not cast a vote. I need the FBI to be independent. "So, you couldn't cast a vote in the privacy of the ballot box or through the mail box?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Such a political animal.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: He didn't vote because he didn't Hillary Clinton needed his help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: She's ever going to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he had his finger in the wind and someone said this, I think it was Byron York who made a great point. So, the first meeting you have with the president-elect and you're the FBI Director and you hand him a paper saying that there is shady stuff that Russia has on you. Why do you think President Trump was saying, you know what, loyalty is pretty important, probably because President Trump thought he might be being blackmailed by the FBI director? I mean, that's what I would have thought if the first meeting with the guy, he comes to me and says we have all this dirt on you allegedly from the Russians. I would have been a little suspicious. He was probably just trying to get a read on the guy.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: It's a very foozy situation actually, if you go back and think about it. This is an FBI director who didn't bother to go meet the president-elect until two full months after the election. And he ambles his way up to New York finally, 14 days before the inauguration and laid this bomb at the feet of the president-elect after everybody else left the room, but made clear to the president then, when he made clear to him many other times before, but failed to disclose publicly, which is that the president himself was not under investigation. He refused to say that...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He told him three times he wasn't under investigation.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: He told him at least three times, but wouldn't say it publicly. This person, this Comey guy who had no problem leaking information to the New York Times asking McCabe to do it to the Wall Street Journal at least doing it with his knowledge and then leaking it with an eye toward and a hope to getting -- triggering a special counsel, which is what happened. Why not just tell the public that the FBI director told the president-elect that he is not under investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, why not, Kellyanne? Well, that's a great point because we have it right here. Because again, President Trump asking the FBI Director, tell me what you just said before. I am not under investigation. Say that to the general public. He says, "I returned the president's call this morning. We spoke for about four minutes. He said he was following up to see if I did what he had asked last time, getting out that he was personally not under investigation. I replied that I had passed the request to the Acting AG and had not heard back from him." So, why is Shady James Comey, love the new nickname by the way, why is he slow walking the effort to make the public aware that the president of the United States is not under investigation. Why would he do that?

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Well, he doesn't have a good answer for that himself. If I had to guess, because the wrong person won the election. He was taking all types of incoming from his friends in the Democratic Party. The people who had been investigating Hillary Clinton at the highest levels of the FBI, who we know through their sexting now, I mean, texting now, Jesse. I didn't like President Trump very much. Had it in for him. They have since been reassigned. Peter and his wife, Andrew McCabe and his wife. I mean, it's all a big toxic brew with Jim Comey at the top not acting like a leader. More to the point, this is somebody who went on a book tour, who was absolutely a witness in the Mueller investigation and himself admitted, that he probably will be -- he most likely will be a witness in the McCabe criminal investigation now, and he's out there breaking protocol with the FBI and the DOJ yet again by diverting the spotlight onto himself. One thing happened to Jim Comey though this week, whether it's the New York Times podcast on Friday or Jake Tapper on Thursday, he thought he'd get a hero's welcome among the mainstream media.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: And some of them have not been tough on him at all, but some have been really probing and scrutinizing the veracity of his claims. It's been really tough for him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right and Kellyanne, I have a whole list of things that he violated in terms of protocol and statute, so he could be looking at some serious consequences. Thank you very much, Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: CONWAY
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Coming up, the most outrageous stories of the week with two of the most outrageous people I know. We will be right back.

utterances.speaker: MOLLIE LINE, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News Headquarters", I am Molly Line. Mourners gathering in Texas today for the funeral of Barbara Bush. Today's services attended by an estimated 1,500 people including First Lady, Melania Trump, as well as former Presidents Obama and Clinton and their wives. The funeral was held in Houston at the Bush's family church and per the former first lady's request, was a very simple service. Mrs. Bush died Tuesday at the age of 92. Meanwhile, President Trump coming to the defense of his personal attorney, Michael Cohen who is under Federal investigation for his business practices. A New York Times story suggests Cohen may turn on his client, but Mr. Trump attacked that idea and the newspaper in a series of tweets. Saying The Times is going out of its way to destroy Cohen and their relationship. I am Molly Line, now back to "Watters' World".

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time for this week's most outrageous stories. First up, a tenured professor at California State University at Fresno taking to Twitter just hours after the passing of Former First Lady Barbara Bush to write this vile message. "Barbara Bush was a generous, smart and amazing racist who along with her husband raised a war criminal. F' outta here with your nice words." Adding, "PSA, either you're against these pieces of-- and their genocidal ways or you're part of the problem. That's actually how simple this is. I am happy the witch is dead. Can't wait for the rest of her family to fall to their demise the way 1.5 million Iraqis have." Joining me now, Fox News contributor Tomi Lahren and actor, Stephen Baldwin. I mean disgusting individual. She is tenured. She is bragging about how she is tenured, Tomi, so you can't fire her. I am not so sure about that because Fresno is actually reviewing her status at the University. You're a California person, I think you should pay this professor a visit.

utterances.speaker: TOMI LAHREN, CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: I'd love to. I'd love to go pay her a visit and see you know what she has to say outside of, of course, the barriers of Twitter. But, I think furthermore, it's disgusting, it's wrong, but she thinks she can get away with it because this is a liberal college campus 101. They think they can get away with it because they often do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, she is used to saying things like that. What you call those people? Keyboard warriors. You know, they are very bold when they are behind the keyboard, but I don't think she'd say that to the family's face. What about you?

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN BALDWIN, AMERICAN ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Well, I agree with Tomi. It's quite obvious, but what's interesting to me too, Jesse, is the more we let these folks yodel, the more we let them get on Twitter and just poop their brains out you know, et cetera et cetera. The more those folks that voted for Mr. Trump get the confirmation and they start looking at these folks and they start looking at progressives on the left and they go, "You know what, I don't agree with that."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, this helps the president and the movement because you see people like this and you say, "That's why I voted for Donald Trump." I want to show some sound from our friend Keith Ellison. I know you guys are very tight, Tomi. Congressman Democrat actually had this to say about voting Republican. Let's hear it.

utterances.speaker: KEITH ELLISON, US REPRESENTATIVE, MINESOTTA, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: Did you know that in Missouri and in Texas and maybe other places, maternal mortality has risen. Women are dying because we are losing elections. We don't have the right to lose a damn election. We have to win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So voting for Republicans kills people. Women especially.

utterances.speaker: LAHREN
utterances.utterance: It kills women, and you know, funny thing is, I am a woman, I voted for President Trump and I couldn't be happier. So, I don't know what he's talking about or what he's referring to, but again, it just shows that's the only card they have in the deck is the victim card. Sad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We want to keep you alive, Tomi. We don't want you to die. We like you here on Fox News. Baldwin, why are you dancing?

utterances.speaker: BALDWIN
utterances.utterance: Go Tomi, go Tomi, it's your birthday, it's your birthday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I knew that that's why I had you guys together.

utterances.speaker: BALDWIN
utterances.utterance: But she's great. You know what I mean? Because I can relate. You know, obviously it's a little difficult to stand up and you know, represent what you believe in, in this current, you know waters, no pun intended.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One...

utterances.speaker: BALDWIN
utterances.utterance: But again, it's more of the same mayhem. It's more of a messaging that just isn't working. It's not working for Democrats. I think obviously in this next round of elections, people are going to be just shocked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If that's the Democratic message for the midterms, they are in deep trouble. Wasn't he also palling around with Farrakhan? I didn't think he would be able to top that, I guess he just did. Let's here Joe Biden -- Smoking Joe Biden, he was on with Al Sharpton, the reverend and had this to say about Republicans.
